Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Strong wind transport with visibility zero at regular intervals in the day. The intensity of the wind and blowing snow made pit observations difficult. It was difficult to know how much precipitation was taking place due to the wind transport. The new snow at the surface has become denser and is beginning to act like a slab.
HS 410, SH is decomposing

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: PST notes: I felt a small collapse at 80/150. however, after examining couldn't find any signs of propagation. I continued to cut and had full propagation at 120/150 to the end. The crust layer appears to be breaking down, and the faceted grains above and below appear to be rounding to the naked eye.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We picked this wind loaded safe spot to check reactivity of the new wind slab. Upper bowl was visibly either scoured or wind loaded. Below treeline and below the bowl slopes were not wind affected. This location only represents the areas recently wind loaded. We also noted a crown off the false summit of Mt Troy that appeared to have occurred during the wind event and was ~40-70cm deep and 50-80' wide. The crown from the Jan 1st human triggered slide was still visible in the bowl.
Bare dirt prior to December. PST weak layer...not so weak, hard to keep the blade on the interface.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug on a representative adjacent slope to HS-N-R2-D3-O in West Monitor Bowl the day prior. Similar slab depth, similar weak layer. ECTP 30+ aligns with PST 60/150 (end) down 20. It is getting difficult to trigger these large slides but if you do there is great destructive potential.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Test Pit dug NE of Brochard Gondola Top Station on Traverse towards Col des Rachasses. The recent rain event up to 3000m has left the snow surface in blank ice and a 3 cm thick crust at this elevation on northfacing aspects. While the layer of facets below the crust is not a concern currently, it will be interesting to watch it when it gets loaded with subsequent snowfall, especially at the elevation band around 2800-3000m where the crust is thin but present.
Mycket tydlig lägormation i övrigt mycket mindre snö.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: UDOT BCC Monthly pit December 2021 Spruces plot. HS Dec 1st = ~1". MF crusts not present in higher elevation start zones. Thin snowpack at study plot shows high temp gradient driving faceting throughout pack, especially localized near mid-pack P-hard MF crust.
område med bara ny drevsnö. Planar feature.
Ej repressentativ för större delen av terrängen. Mycket få platser med mer än 20 cm snö.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Vestangola með smá ofankomu. Skýjað. Snjópakki er nokkuð þéttur og greinilega vindbarinn. Gerði 2 samþjöppunarpróf. Annað féll ekkert saman en seinna á 23 í 14cm. Við álag myndast hrein brot á ýmsum stöðum. Gryfja var misdjúp og lækur undir hluta hennar. Þegar lokið var við gryfjutöku jókst vindur og snjókoma.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ski cut several ASc-L-D1-S in Rolly Bowl that failed within the storm snow, 20-25cm down. Persistent Slabs were being stubborn and weren't getting good results on these. The road from Rocky Flats headed to Summit Lake is super bumpy.

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Substantial avi debris in all gullies leading from Bedaden Powell summit East gully, NE gullies, N gully debris crossed Hwy 2, ripped out guard rails trees and ran to Big Rock Creek. Debris on road bench at north gully approx 10' high, 50' wide. Avi debris field in North face old growth crossing summer approach PCT trail. Avi debris field on the north face approximatley 100-125 yards wide and appeared starting zone was at slope breakover point at top of switchbacks. Could not see top of debris field crown line. Very substantial avalanch activity in this area.

The PST test on this pit suggests extreme care if going into the North Facing woods at lower elevations in Pinedale. Both ECT and PST revealed fracture potential. The PST cut length was just slightly under 20cm for a 160cm column, which is very short for this sort of test. The instability is deep enough that you can't feel it under foot while skiing. No collapsing no cracking on our tour.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ski cuts produced multiple DL releases in upper 20-25cm of storm snow. Much of the face of Rolly Bowl slid a few weeks ago and now 90-100cm depth, mostly facetted, and lots of sharks hiding under the surface. PS are being stubborn and mostly nonreactive in our tests. Dug a hasty pit on skier's far right of the standard ski run.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 20211231 08300 Nimrod, NE 9,000' SS-Ec-R3-D1.5-I All intentionally triggered avalanches in the morning failed and propagated in storm snow and new/old snow interface, similarly, to test results in pit. These layers however are not my greatest concern because of the greater size potential of the 49cm layer and its smooth planner (Q1) in tests.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I was surprised to see facets at the ground. In most places the bottom 10 cm or so of the snowpack is very hard, icy snow from the wet October snow.
This profile resembles many other places including north facing slopes, the only difference is that the fc'ed/DH layer at 22 cm above the ground is thicker and often has larger grains.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit location was chosen to be representative of mid elevation NE terrain. 40 cm of advanced facets exist near the ground. Structure is a big red flag but time since loading has increased stability. For Now...Block failed after 30+ taps.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Instability rapidly rising; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Post ECT test moderate shear SC down 100 on Fist hard facets.
First time in Summit Park this season. Even with this past storm cycle everything besides true north is thin and bony. Did three laps last two with Nolan

A small steeper rock bulge next to the duck pass trail ~200m from the trail to the west, adjacent to Arrowhead Lake outlet. Open sky and under the top of a short ridge exposed to lots of wind. Testing and measurements were a bit hastier than I'd have liked, Tamarack has no "free" side for the most part, and I got a late start, however, I would consider most of the info to be mostly accurate.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit location chosen to represent east aspects that have old October PWL at the ground. Slopes with this PWL have poor stability and will be the areas of highest concern. Two 1kg hand charges were used prior to pit with no results but still easy propagating shear with ECT.
Open meadow below ridge top.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit location chosen to represent near treeline aspect with little to no October PWL. Profile was right-side up and almost entirely recent storm snow. Aspects that were free of old snow prior to December storm cycle have good stability.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Winds blowing from the West the day previously loaded snow on the Eastern and NorthEastern aspects of the ridgeline, scoring much of the windward face near the peaks and creating impressive leeward cornices.
Open glade, rough bed surface.
Found a generally stable snowpack. We dug a pit looking for persistent problems. None were found in this area.
This slope has been previously wind loaded over the last few days HS is almost double of what other folks have found in the area.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Got a whumpf on the layer of concern about 100 ft from where we dug. Area that collapsed was approx. 50' radius. Large natural avalanche (2800' wide, 2-3' deep, 2000' vert) from previous 24 hrs about a half mile north of the pit location. HS-N-R3-D3-O
Strong winds with blowing snow, did not bother with grain type/size

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ridgeline winds were West/Moderate with Light transport. We encountered 2x collapses on approach to snowpit site. CT & ECT fail at 35cm on buried NSF.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This avalanche trigged another avalanche sympathetically lower down on the slope on a similar aspect and steep slope angle. SS-AS/c-R2-D1-I
Primarily looking for deep layers of concern, basal facets.
Very quick pit without much detail. This pit was above the crown of a shooting crack that propagated about 30 feet on a slope then slide about a foot downslope before coming to a rest
Slight wind loading
